weka.classifiers.functions.wisard

Class Discriminator

  • java.lang.Object
    • weka.classifiers.functions.wisard.Discriminator
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, RevisionHandler

    public class Discriminator
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable, RevisionHandler
    Description: Implements the WiSARD weightless neural model. The Discriminator is an array of RAMs with 2^n storage locations. Each RAM is stimulated in writing (training) and reading (classification) mode by accessing one of its locations by means of an input integer address (between 0 and 2n - 1). a tuple is an array of integer addresses for RAMs, with as many elements as the number of RAMs.

    Depending on the type of input data to learn/classify we need to encode the input into a array of integer addresses for RAMs.

    • if the input is a binary vector, then a partition of it into n-sized tuples is obtained (linearly or randomly). Extracted tuples of bits are decoded into integers used to access RAMs' locations.
    • if the input is a vector of real data with size m, first, the vector values are scaled-up and discretized to a value v in the range of integers: 0, z-1; each value is translated into the thermometer encoding: a sequence of v bits set followed by z-v bits unset. The bits sequences are arranged one after the other to form a binary input vector with size z × m. Then, the encoding of the binary input vector is like in the previous case.
    For more information on WiSARD model, see

    Massimo De Gregorio and Maurizio Giordano (2018).
    An experimental evaluation of weightless neural networks for multi-class classification.
    Journal of Applied Soft Computing. Vol.72. pp. 338-354

    See Also:

      • Discriminator

        public Discriminator(int n_bit,
                     int size,
                     java.lang.String name,
                     mapType mt,
                     long seed)
              throws weka.classifiers.functions.wisard.WisardException
        Discriminator constructor
        Parameters:
        n_bit - number of bits for keys of RAMs
        size - the input binary input size
        name - of discriminator
        mt - the mapping type (the options are LINEAR or RANDOM)
        seed - seed random mapping. Can be -1 (no seed) of a valid noninteger seed.
        Throws:
        WisardException - error in construction

    • Method Detail

      • checkTuple

        public java.lang.Boolean checkTuple(long[] tuple)
        Check if the input is a legal tuple for the discriminator.
        Parameters:
        tuple - the input tuple of keys
        Returns:
        true if the input is a legal tuple for the discriminator

      • trainHisto

        public void trainHisto(double[] data,
                       double[] range,
                       double[] off,
                       int z,
                       int nattr)
        Train on the discriminator on one sample of data. Before training, input data vector is scaled and discretized to a integer vector; then binarized using the 'thermometer' encoding. the resulting binary vector is transformed to a set of keys to access discriminators RAMs.
        Parameters:
        data - the input vector of real numbers
        range - the array of value intervals of each component of data
        off - the array of offsets (min values) of each component of data
        z - the range of integer values (from 0 to z-1) the datum may assume after discretization
        nattr - the number of data vector components (attributes of sample data)

      • train

        public void train(long[] tuple)
           throws weka.classifiers.functions.wisard.WisardException
        Train on the discriminator on one input tuple of keys to access discriminators RAMs
        Parameters:
        tuple - the input tuple of keys for RAMs
        Throws:
        WisardException - error if tuple is not legal for the discriminator

      • classifyHisto

        public double classifyHisto(double[] data,
                            double[] range,
                            double[] off,
                            int z,
                            int nattr)
        Classify one sample of data by summing-then-averaging responses of discriminators. (responses are not stored in discriminator objects). Before classification, input data vector is scaled and discretized to a integer vector; then binarized using the 'thermometer' encoding. the resulting binary vector is transformed to a set of keys to access discriminators RAMs.
        Parameters:
        data - the input vector of real numbers
        range - the array of value intervals of each component of data
        off - the array of offsets (min values) of each component of data
        z - the range of integer values (from 0 to z-1) the datum may assume after discretization
        nattr - the number of data vector components (attributes of sample data)
        Returns:
        the classification response (a double in the range 0,1)

      • classify

        public double classify(long[] tuple)
                throws weka.classifiers.functions.wisard.WisardException
        Classify on an input tuple of keys to access discriminators RAMs.
        Parameters:
        tuple - the input tuple of keys for RAMs
        Returns:
        the classification response (a double in the range 0,1)
        Throws:
        WisardException - error if tuple is not legal for the discriminator

      • responseHisto

        public void responseHisto(double[] data,
                          double[] range,
                          double[] off,
                          int z,
                          int nattr)
        Computes (and stores) responses of each discriminator on one sample of data. Before getting responses, input data vector is scaled and discretized to a integer vector; then binarized using the 'thermometer' encoding. the resulting binary vector is transformed to a set of keys to access discriminators RAMs.
        Parameters:
        data - the input vector of real numbers
        range - the array of value intervals of each component of data
        off - the array of offsets (min values) of each component of data
        z - the range of integer values (from 0 to z-1) the datum may assume after discretization
        nattr - the number of data vector components (attributes of sample data)
